instance_metrics.response: My family was so poor, we couldn't afford to have a family car. We had a family unicycle. It was tough, especially with five kids. My dad would pedal, my mom would balance, and us kids would take turns sitting on the handlebars, the seat, and even the back fender. We'd argue about whose turn it was to be the "wheel warmer" – the one who had to run alongside and hold the frame when we went uphill. One time, my little brother fell off and yelled, "Mom, Dad, I think I broke my leg!" My dad, without missing a beat, called back, "Just rub some dirt on it, son! We're almost there!" My mom then added, "And don't forget to tie your shoelace, we can't afford to lose a shoe!" We eventually got a car, but honestly, those unicycle days were some of the best. We learned teamwork, resilience, and the true meaning of a family sticking together – literally!

(متفق عليه: البخاري 47، مسلم 945).*   وعن علي بن أبي طالب رضي الله عنه قال: سمعت رسول الله صلى الله عليه وسلم يقول: "مَنْ غَسَّلَ مَيْتًا فَسَتَرَهُ، سَتَرَهُ اللَّهُ مِنَ الذُّنُوبِ، وَمَنْ كَفَّنَ مَيْتًا كَسَاهُ اللَّهُ مِنَ السُّنْدُسِ، وَمَنْ حَمَلَ مَيْتًا مَشَى بَيْنَ يَدَيْهِ مَلَائِكَةٌ، وَمَنْ صَلَّى عَلَى مَيْتٍ شُفِّعَ فِيهِ، وَمَنْ شَيَّعَ مَيْتًا حَتَّى يُدْفَنَ، كَانَ لَهُ بِكُلِّ خُطْوَةٍ كَأَجْرِ حَجَّةٍ مَبْرُورَةٍ، وَمَنْ عَزَّى مَيْتًا كَانَ لَهُ بِكُلِّ خُطْوَةٍ كَأَجْرِ شَهِيدٍ". instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Spain, trying to order a drink, confidently asked the bartender, "Dos cervezas, por favor."The bartender, a jovial man, smiled and replied, "Ah, you want two beers! Coming right up!"The tourist, delighted by the quick understanding, then added, "And for my friend, he wants a *vaca*."The bartender's smile faltered. He scratched his head. "A… *vaca*? Sir, that means 'cow' in Spanish. Are you sure your friend wants a whole cow to drink?"The tourist, equally confused, insisted, "Yes, a *vaca*! You know, like the drink? The one that's red and comes in a bottle?"The bartender finally burst out laughing. "Ah, sir! You mean *vino*! Wine! Not a *vaca*! Unless your friend is exceptionally thirsty for dairy and has a very large stomach!"

instance_metrics.response: A tourist in a small European village was trying to find a specific landmark. He stopped a local and, pointing to his map, asked, "Excuse me, sir, can you tell me where the *bibliothèque* is?"The local, a kindly old man, squinted at the map and then looked at the tourist, a puzzled expression on his face. "The *biblio-what*?" he asked, struggling with the pronunciation.The tourist, thinking the man hadn't heard him, repeated, a little louder, "The *bibliothèque*! You know, where they keep the books?"The old man's eyes widened. "Ah, *books*!" he exclaimed, a lightbulb going off. "Why didn't you just say so? We don't have a *bibliothèque* here, but we have a lovely little bookstore just around the corner!"

instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Spain, trying to practice his rudimentary Spanish, walks into a bakery. He points to a delicious-looking pastry and asks the baker, "Disculpe, ¿puedo tener uno de estos... um... *burros*?"The baker, a kindly woman with a puzzled expression, looks at him for a moment, then bursts out laughing. "¡Señor! ¡Eso es un *bollo*! Un *burro* es un animal, ¡y no creo que quiera comer uno de esos!"The tourist, mortified, blushes bright red. "Oh! *Bollo*! Right! My apologies, I seem to have mixed up my animals and my baked goods!"The baker, still chuckling, hands him the pastry. "No hay problema, señor. Es un error común. Pero le aseguro, este *bollo* es mucho más sabroso que cualquier *burro* que haya probado."The tourist leaves with his pastry, and a newfound respect for the subtle differences in Spanish vocabulary, vowing to study his dictionary more diligently. He also made a mental note to never ask for a "donkey" in a bakery again.

instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Spain, trying to practice his Spanish, walks into a bakery and points at a delicious-looking pastry. "Quiero este," he proudly declares, meaning "I want this."The baker, a kindly old woman, smiles and nods. "Ah, the 'Este.' Very good, sir. That will be two euros."The tourist is a bit confused but pays and leaves with his pastry. The next day, he returns, eager for another. He points again, "Quiero este."The baker beams. "Another 'Este'! You have excellent taste, sir. Two euros."This goes on for a week. Every day, the tourist buys an "Este." Finally, on the seventh day, he decides he's brave enough to ask. "Señora," he begins, "what exactly *is* an 'Este'?"The baker chuckles, "An 'Este,' my dear sir, is simply what you get when you point at something and say, 'This one!'"

instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Rome was trying to order a coffee. He pointed to the menu item "latte" and proudly declared, "I'll have a latte!" The barista looked at him confused and replied, "Sir, this is a coffee shop. We have many lattes. Do you mean a Caffè latte?"The tourist, a bit flustered, tried again, "No, no, just a latte. You know, milk." The barista's confusion deepened. "Milk? You want a glass of milk? We have that, but usually people order coffee *with* milk."Finally, a local customer stepped in and, with a smile, explained to the barista, "He means a 'Caffè latte,' but in English, 'latte' alone often refers to the coffee drink." The tourist, relieved, nodded vigorously. The barista, chuckling, finally understood. "Ah, *that* latte! Why didn't you just say 'coffee with milk'?"The tourist sighed and said, "Because in my country, 'latte' *is* coffee with milk!"

instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Spain, trying to practice his Spanish, walks into a bakery and points to a delicious-looking pastry. "Quiero este," he says confidently, meaning "I want this."The baker, a kindly woman, smiles and nods, then hands him a small, plain bread roll. Confused, the tourist points again to the pastry. "No, no, *este*!" he insists, a little louder.The baker, still smiling, hands him another plain roll. Frustrated, the tourist tries a different approach. He mimes eating the pastry, making appreciative noises.The baker claps her hands, her face lighting up with understanding. "Ah!" she exclaims. "¡Usted quiere *ese*!"She then hands him a small, plain bread roll. The tourist, utterly defeated, takes the roll and slumps out of the bakery, muttering, "I guess I'll just have to *roll* with it."Later, he discovers that "este" (this) refers to something close to the speaker, while "ese" (that) refers to something close to the listener. He had been pointing to a pastry that was close to *him*, but the baker understood he wanted something close to *her* – which happened to be the plain rolls on the counter.
instance_metrics.prompt: Tell me a joke about language misunderstandings

instance_metrics.response: A linguist, a philosopher, and a programmer walk into a bar.The bartender asks, "What can I get for you folks?"The linguist says, "I'll have a beer, but could you tell me the etymology of the word 'bar' first? I'm curious about its semantic evolution and how it came to denote both a drinking establishment and a physical obstruction."The philosopher, deep in thought, interjects, "Before that, perhaps we should question the very nature of 'having' a beer. Does one truly possess the beer, or merely experience its fleeting presence? And what of the 'you' in your question, bartender? Is it a universal 'you,' or specific to us three?"The programmer, exasperated, slams his hand on the counter. "Look, guys, can we just get a drink? I'm trying to debug my life and this is not helping. I just want a 'bar' in the sense of a place where I can consume a 'beer' in the sense of an alcoholic beverage. No more parsing necessary!"The bartender, completely bewildered, just stares at them. After a long pause, he says, "So... three beers, then?"

He pointed to a delicious-looking croissant and, wanting to ask if it was fresh, confidently declared, "Bonjour! instance_metrics.response: A tourist in Italy, eager to practice his fledgling Italian, walked into a restaurant and proudly announced to the waiter, "Vorrei un tavolo per due, ma non voglio mangiare."The waiter, a kindly old man, looked puzzled. "Signore," he replied, "You wish for a table for two, but you do not wish to eat?"The tourist, beaming, nodded vigorously. "Sì, sì! Non voglio mangiare. Voglio solo sedermi."The waiter, now even more confused, scratched his head. "But... why would you want a table if you don't intend to eat? Our tables are for dining."The tourist, growing a little frustrated, tried to explain in broken English, "No, no, not *eat*! I want to *sit*! Sedersi! Like... like a chair, but a table!"The waiter, finally understanding the source of the confusion, chuckled. "Ah, signore! You mean you want to *reserve* a table, not *not eat*! The word you are looking for is 'prenotare'!"The tourist's face went red. "Oh! Right! 'Prenotare'! Not 'non voglio mangiare'!"They both had a good laugh, and the tourist successfully reserved his table for two, promising to actually *eat* this time.

But if you want, I can lend you mine!)The tourist, now utterly confused, stammers, "No, no, el baño... para *ir* al baño!" Pues, en mi casa, está en el cuarto de dormir. ¡Pero no te lo recomiendo, es un poco pequeño para nadar!" (Oh, I understand! To *go* to the bath! Well, in my house, it's in the bedroom. instance_metrics.response: My grandpa always told me, "Son, if you want to be successful, just keep your head down and never ask for anything."So I did. Now I just leave passive-aggressive notes in the break room about the lack of decent coffee. I'm sure that'll get me that corner office with a window. Any day now.
